Welcome to /k/, 4chan's weapons board. Our board centers around weapons, armor, and other myriad military technology. While guns are the primary topic, threads involving any other sort of weapons, from swords and knives to tanks and jet fighters, come up frequently as well. If you're new, we suggest reading the sticky at http://amagicalplace.wikia.com/wiki/Sticky to get acquainted with the board's subject matter.

Before posting a thread, please check our catalog to ensure that a thread about the same topic does not already exist.

threads.com:
Today, I have a treat for you, /k/ommandos.

In my country (Czech), we have a police museum. Every interesting thing cops have ever found somewhere ends up there. One of these things is a beautifully crafted, rather interesting .22 pistol on a particularly unique belt (picrel). Both of these things were found in the early 90s on a dead body of a very interesting individual. And even though the man was dead for some time, when police officers found his corpse, one of the cops nearly got shot. I will post details about both. I guarantee you'll enjoy this one.

threads.com:
Question for those of you in Law Enforcement/National Guard/Military. If you take away film plot convenience, how would escalation to a monstrous threat work?

Like, a patrol car or some animal control shows up and finds out that for once, the panicking people on the other side of the phone are right this is not a bear this is some scary shit. It kills an officer but one survives.

What do you tell to the station? Supposing backup arrives, they see it too and shoot at it and it just kills more. This isn't a prank.

Do they just keep sending more men? A SWAT team? At what point and how do they approach the state or the military to ask for help and how does one pitch it? Lie and claim its a terrorist attack?

At what point would the military actually decide to act and do anything?

This data is from an era where comms and recon were significantly less developed than they are now. It should be possible to up these engagement ranges to some degree.

Also, if 20% of your engagements are occuring at 300m then that's a large enough share to warrant some consideration. You don't want to be out of your effective range 1:5 times.

People seems to have a hard time distinguishing between the effective range of a weapon and "can someone on YouTube still plink a still target at that distance."

There is a reason that, when weight isn't as much of an issue (mounted machine guns for example), .50 cal is preferred, or at least 7.62mm. Arguably the benefits of the lower maximum ordinate are greater for indirect fire, but it's still nice to have on your rifle.

So the question then becomes one of capacity versus better ballistics. If your opponents have body armor, that's also a consideration.

Dawn of Black Friday deals edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

I read that Mark 23 and fullsize USP 45 magazines are, essentially, the same, they just differ in the floorplates. Mark 23 mags will fit and work on an USP 45 without modifications, whereas USP 45 mags will fit and work on a Mark 23 if you either trim the magwell mouth or swap the floorplate with a Mark 23 one. The latter seems to be the more logical and easier option.

Another thing playing an influence on the German naming convention is that the equivalent of sub - unter isn't understood hierarchically but spatially, like below or under.

Almost everybody understands and uses abbreviations too (MP,SMG,MG) so there is actually not much confusion when it comes to describing and naming categories correctly.

>>56076817
I'm not doing anymore woodworking right now but the process is basically as follows:
>sketch out design, first on paper then in 2d on wood
>cut out approximate shape on bandsaw/scrollsaw, a smooth profile is important since it's harder to round out material if there's jagged edges
>place hand on top of blank, then draw approximate areas where your hand will fall during use
>using bandsaw, belt sander, and half round rough rasps, carve down these grooves while periodically placing your hand on the piece and marking high spots that dig into your palm. for flats I use a Shinto saw rasp which works great
>for the mounting bolts I used socket head cap screws, so I first drilled two long, thin holes for the shaft of the screws and then bored out the top ~0.5" with a wider drill bit to countersink the cap of the screw. If you have to cut any screws, thread a nut on first so it cleans up the threads when you remove it.
>once shape is comfortable, switch to a finer file and rough grit sandpaper, working up the grits to about 250. At the higher grits, you can wet the wood and sand over the fine fibers that stick up to get a smoother result
>finish the wood with some sort of sealant - I usually just use linseed oil but there's plenty of "professional" finishes to choose from
Eventually I'll make a new grip since I don't love how this one makes you hold the rifle, so once I do that I'll make a thread/video on it

>>56082564
>nope, see pic.
That's a Konkurs-M, not Konkurs. And while it has multiple control surfaces, most of them are fixed. Only one pair is actuated.
You can see how the orange set of fins in the front is angled in order to keep the missile spinning in flight.
> TOW even in your video is spiraling
Spiraling as in the missile rotates in flight, which the TOW does not do because that would tangle it's control cables. TOW stays in one orientation during flight. Look at the counter clockwise exhaust pattern in the Shtora video to see why it's not a TOW but rather a spinning Russian/Soviet ATGM.

The guy who said it was impossible to jam wire-guided ATGM is retarded. Early ATGM's "jammed themselves" because the control system could not tell it's ATGM from any other ATGM in the viewfinder. The big improvement in TOW-2 was modulating the flare so the launcher knows which flare is "it's" missile. Which is also why Shtora can't jam TOW-2.
